text: Is it possible to name an app with a third-party integration name, e.g. "Google Task Connector" if I want to make a Google Task integration? I see other partners doing this on the marketplace, I just wanted to make sure that it's possible :slightly_smiling_face:

You have to comply with trademark laws. A user should never confuse your app for the app you’re connecting their account to.

For example If you’re not Google, your name should not imply you are.

I’d consult a lawyer that knows trademark law if you intend to use the name of a third party in your app name or any marketing materials.

Also HubSpot’s App Marketplace is not actively vetting whether you have license to use a trademark, that is your responsibility. For example if you named your app “Nintendo” HubSpot’s app marketplace could theoretically allow your app in, but Nintendo would have legal right due to the trademark to come after you. I’m not a lawyer, I can’t provide legal advice other than tell you go talk to a lawyer.

What I’ve seen though in tech in trademark disputes in the past (not specific to HubSpot) the owner of the trademark typically wins in court all profits you ever had while using the trademark, as well as potentially additional money for damaging the value of their trademark. If your business used their trademark for a long time, this could bankrupt your entire business.
Does anyone know if a public app that creates custom objects is counted against the accounts limit for custom objects?  Asking for a friend...
Is this documented anywhere that I can reference?
<@U05R380MLMC> I’m pretty sure they do count, as I’ve noticed a number of errors relating to this limit being reached when trying to create a new custom object type (via Public App authentication).
Oh boy - I'd love to get an official statement from HubSpot or API documentation.
